narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about some research methods and what a political science thesis should look like to some extent.
The basics of original research
I am more prepared to write a thesis now than I was at the beginning of the semester.

We talked about research design, coming up with a viable research question, and the structures of political science senior essays. About half the class was structured around individual students' presentations of their projects and plans going forward. During these class meetings, a few students gave powerpoint presentations and the rest of us gave feedback.
I learned how to develop a research question, how to structure a long essay, and how to create measurable steps for myself in the writing process.
We prepared aspects of our senior essays and workshopped them with the group.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed getting to learn about my peers' projects, but at times I felt as though the class was taking up time that I could otherwise have spent writing my essay.

The biggest strength was the meeting with the librarian and how much that helped with getting more sources. Other than that, I really didn't get much out of the course, other than it keeping me on a schedule for my thesis, which was nice. However, I wish we didn't have to spend two hours per week discussing readings that felt irrelevant. I would prefer have two hours to turn on zoom and work on our theses, being able to ask the professor questions if we came across any during our two hour set aside work time.

Strength - Professor Hierro really tries to juggle all 20 ish students' projects which is a difficult task.
Weakness - We often read readings which were very unrelated to most of our projects. Professor Hierro did not give us much time in our groups to actually discuss our projects. I felt I often had no direction or idea of what a senior thesis in Political Science should look like, and my peers felt the same. We often thought Professor Hierro thought we were not trying, but we were lost and could not express it to Professor Hierro. This class should be kept but redesigned with better timelines. The assignments should actually be chunks of our thesis we submit.

Strengths: facilitated one on one time with the professor; provided structure for thesis work

Weaknesses: had a lot of big deadlines but not little ones; for instance, students were asked early own to write a memo describing our research question, motivation, and potential methodology when many had not even pinned down a question. A lot more time near the beginning of the course should have given students research deadlines so that they could pin down a solid research question before moving forward
Many of the assignments bore little connection to thesis writing and seemed more geared to having students just check the boxes.

Strengths: Excellent peer and instructor feedback!!
Weaknesses: Not made for all political science students.

I think the department may want to reconsider this course. I understand the desire to make sure that students writing senior essays receive some exposure to research design, but I think that this course comes a little too late for that, and its focus on discussing research design and workshopping students' designs felt like it kept me in the planning stages of my project when I wanted to be starting on my research. I think that allowing students more time for research during their senior year could help us produce stronger projects. Instead of keeping this course in its current form, I think it could be helpful to have some sort of methods requirement before the senior year so that the class component of this course can be scaled down. Meeting for two hours a week was a lot (and the full two hours of seminar discussion was really, really challenging over Zoom!), so instead of this really being a class, I think it would be much more helpful to have something that met for a shorter span of time during the week and was much more focused on organic discussions among students so that we can talk through our challenges and ideas as we actually do our research, to troubleshoot together. In the Zoom format, I think breakout rooms can be useful to this. So I would support a methods requirement before senior year so that this course can look less like a formal class. 

I think Prof. Hierro made a really strong effort this semester! She was great about giving us very specific and timely comments on our work, and I also appreciated that she solicited student feedback herself on the last day of class and at a few points earlier in the semester. I also liked that Prof. Hierro put us in small groups at the start of the semester based off of our projects, and I would have liked for us to do more in these small groups throughout the semester (especially since we ended up having like 18 people, which is a lot for seminar discussions). Instead of the big, formal presentations in front of the whole class, I would have preferred smaller and more frequent check-ins with the people in my group. 

It was also nice that Prof. Hierro listened to our feedback about the first quiz and designed a second "quiz" assignment that was more suited to our individual projects. Overall, I think she did a good job but the purpose that this class is expected to serve is just very difficult to work with.
It does what it is meant to do. The virtual format took away robbed some of its effect, but I nevertheless found meaning and motivation.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminar ran probably as normal on Zoom. I think Professor Hierro struggled a lot with using Canvas and Zoom which could be improved. It was frustrating sometimes assignments weren't open or she tried to use peer review which was confusing. It only added to the stress of this semester.

There could have been less memo assignments and more preliminary research assignments. The memos added some undue pressure to have a quantity over quality writing done when it should have been the other way around during a pandemic.
NA. One on one meetings were very helpful.

I liked the use of breakout rooms, so I wish we had done more of that. It's so much easier to stay engaged in a small group discussion where we can talk through our own projects in more detail than in a large group discussion, which can be really challenging to manage over Zoom.
Discussion was well-structured, the break mid-class was good for remaining engaged throughout the seminar, and communication was clear!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No, it would be better to spend the two hours per week working on your thesis, rather than in this class.

If you are taking this class, it is because you are writing the senior thesis and you want to have this project for yourself. I did not enjoy this class or gain much from it, but I like having my own thesis and leading a project.
Necessary for PLSC majors writing a year-long thesis
If you want to write an essay, you've got to take this class.

If you are writing a traditional political science essay, this class is great. If you're writing more philosophical, theoretical, or historical work then some of the components of the class may not be as helpful and you'll likely find yourself in the minority of students. If you don't care for peer feedback or don't want to give peer feedback, don't take the class. If you want to research and write on your own schedule, don't take the class.

If you're going to write a year-long senior thesis, this course (or whatever equivalent of it exists at the time) will be required. I thought this course was a bit of a drag, but overall I would still definitely recommend writing a year-long senior thesis! I've learned a lot about (1) what my academic interests actually are, (2) information/recent scholarship related to my academic interests, and (3) political science as a field by coming up with my own project, working with an adviser, and planning to carry out a long-term and serious research project. I would highly recommend! Even if you're not excited about this course, it is doable and you'll still get to spend most of your time on the research and paper itself, not this class.
Yes, helps set a structure to tackle the yearlong essay.
Yes, it is helpful if you are hoping to write a yearlong senior essay and have never written anything of that length or done original research before.
Yes, Professor Hierro is amazing!!
